There have been hundreds of stories shared with my office about how the Affordable Care Act has helped families and residents in my community. This one I needed to share with all of you.   Dear Rep. Polis,  I participated in your town hall meeting by phone Sunday, and I am following up with a personal story regarding my daughter and me, as it relates to the possible loss of the Affordable Care Act. I have been on the Affordable Care Act – better known as Obamacare – since close to its inception.  One year after my fifth and last surgery for breast cancer (my mother is a survivor as well), Grace, my youngest child and beautiful daughter was inconceivably diagnosed with ALL Children's Leukemia. Grace was eight-and-a-half and in third grade, here in Boulder.  As a beautiful girl with a contagious laugh and personality, Grace was pursued and eventually signed with a talent agency that spotted her. So, we were in California, meeting and having photos done during spring break, and Grace was asked to read for Alice in Wonderland (the movie)! After this amazing opportunity, as we flew home, Grace became ill.  Two days later, our family doctor suspected the worst, ran tests, and sent us home to pack before going to check in at Children's Hospital. Our lives changed overnight, as the unimaginable "journey," as it's called, began. My husband was at a loss, wringing his hands and crying. I put my work on the back-burner and became a full-time advocate for my daughter's survival. Grace endured 26 months of extensive "treatment;” one year of which included up to 3-4 intensive chemo therapy sessions per week. We called me the “shock absorber”, doing whatever was necessary for Grace’s survival and to make it tolerable for her. Following the first year of intensive treatment, we were given a gift of some family counseling, and were actually diagnosed with PTSD, as a family; myself in particular.  Without health insurance, we could not - would not have survived. We will be forever grateful to our family, friends, community, and wonderful school, who rallied at our side, but the cost of giving up my work and the supplemental expenses involved in treatment of a life-threatening disease are a struggle alone; we never could have sustained 26 needed months of treatment, economically. There is no doubt it would have necessitated bankruptcy, and possibly the inability to complete treatment. In addition, there is subsequent treatment.   Child cancer survivors are "followed for life" in a different division of Children's (the "Hope Clinic"), with follow-up labs, scans and check-ups, as the after-effects of certain intensive chemos can range from weakened heart muscles, infertility, endocrine-related issues and many more; let alone the learning disabilities that the after-effects of chemo typically bring. I must say that we continue to struggle, as it is, to get our family back on its feet. The thought of trying to imagine doing that "journey" without the assistance of healthcare--in other words, without the support of our U.S. government is unimaginable. And looking at it that way, it would instill a sense that our country, our government does not care about us--the taxpayers. Again, unimaginable. It brings the tears back to my own eyes.  Thank you for your support, for caring about your constituents, Jared, and for your tireless work. Our community has great appreciation of you!  Best Regards,  Marcia

Dear President Donald J. Trump,  Today, I wanted to write briefly on a topic that has been extraordinarily troubling to my community. That is your administration’s war on science.  I’m proud to represent a district that is home to world-renowned research and science facilities. Our federal laboratories and institutions are sources of ingenuity and generate advancements ranging from lifesaving devices to renewable energy tech to weather prediction tools. They provide good-paying professional jobs that do important work in the public interest, and help our community attract and retain a highly educated workforce, which in-turn fuels further innovation.  Since I’ve been in office, there has never been a time until now when hundreds of acclaimed scientists, researchers, and analysts have called my office worried about losing funding for research projects and scientific programs. I believe when some of the brightest minds in the world call my office, at the bare minimum, we should listen, and more likely than not, we should act.  Mr. President, we’re at a critical time; at this moment, some of the most intelligent thinkers on our planet are extraordinarily concerned about the direction that we’re heading with regard to our nation’s acceptance of science, and also worried that decades of progress are about to come to a halt because of your administration’s inability to accept scientific facts, theories, and publications.  Mr. President, your administration must accept science and the validity of the scientific process, or it will take our country and world into a tailspin economically. You must accept the fact that dismantling our federal laboratories, crippling science budgets, and placing a gag order on scientific agencies harms our nation’s growth and prosperity.   I strongly urge you to support and fully fund our federal research laboratories and research grants to our Universities. America must continue to be a model on the global platform for innovators, entrepreneurs, and leaders in the scientific community. For America to be great, we need to continue to be the global leader in science.  Mr. President, please understand that the scientific community is not only beneficial to the American economy, but also vital for the betterment of humankind.  Writing this to you in 2017,  Rep. Jared Polis (D-Colo.)  Proudly representing the Second Congressional District of Colorado and several outstanding scientific and research institutions including: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) , National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), and high quality research institutions University of Colorado Boulder, and Colorado State University.

This morning we covered immigration and trade in our meeting between US and Mexican legislators. I spoke out for including stronger environmental and labor standards and enforcement, as well as suggested coming up with a way of resolving interstate disputes without putting health, safety, and environmental protections at risk.  On immigration, the Mexican Representatives expressed how hurtful our President's insults have been. I let everyone know how grateful we are that we have many Mexican nationals in Colorado, some of whom plan to return to Mexico and others who plan to become American and that they are critical not only for our economy but also our culture and society. We then went outside for a group picture and quick lunch, and now our meeting is beginning again to discuss security and "a border for the 21st century" and work on our joint declaration.

We succeeded! ¡Tenemos éxito!  I am proud that our group of Mexican and American legislators from all political parties came together in a joint declaration of support for the close friendship between the United States and Mexico and a renewed desire to work together on immigration, security, trade, and border improvements.  Our work shows that Democrats and Republicans, members of PRI, PAN, PRD, and MORENA all value the close friendship and ties between our two great nations.  At our final roundtable, I made the point that our relationship will not only endure but can become stronger despite the ignorant rhetoric of our President. The Foreign Emoluments Clause prohibits any officer of the U.S. from accepting anything of value from any foreign government or its agents or instrumentalities without prior Congressional consent. This means that it is unconstitutional for a President to receive financial benefits from foreign countries while serving our nation.  President Trump has failed to separate himself from his business holdings in any meaningful way.  Since taking office, he has continued to receive payments and other benefits from many foreign governments -all without Congressional consent. Whether it’s payments for rooms and events at the Trump Hotel in Washington from the Embassy of Kuwait, the government of Georgia, and a lobbying firm working for Saudi Arabia; lease payments for space in Trump Tower paid by the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and the United Arab Emirates; or the countless other business and property interests abroad which we might not even know about.  I don’t take this action lightly, but I firmly believe politicians have an obligation to follow the Constitution, and it certainly appears that the President is in violation of the Emoluments Clause.  In the U.S. everyone needs to be equally accountable under the law.

When the floods came four years ago today, we committed to one another to be Colorado strong and rebuild. In the years since the flood, I have been amazed by the resiliency of so many affected. For my family it meant a flooded basement and the loss of some of our treasured family photographs stored there. For others, it upended their entire lives.   Stu and Sarah Jane were new parents to their 9 mo. old daughter when the flood waters demolished their house in Fourmile Canyon.  Shortly after receiving a reverse-911 call, the canyon gave way.  The young family escaped to a firehouse up the canyon, and were offered refuge by a kind stranger.  After two days, a National Guard helicopter, like the one I went on and helped pick up survivors, flew in transporting all three to safety.  It was harrowing, but Stu says his family was fortunate – the smallest difference in circumstances would have meant his family wouldn’t be alive today.  I met Stu and Sarah Jane about 18 months after the flood.  They were trying to rebuild their lives, but were tied up in their mortgage on the flood-ravished house.   We were able to call attention to their situation, along with situation of so many others, by inviting the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Regional Director to tour the area.  That visit helped speed up the arduous process of buyouts, allowing the State and County to buy properties at pre-flood value.  For families like Stu and Sarah Jane’s, the buyout spelled relief after years of paying for a mortgage on a house that was destroyed, and allowed them to start over in a new house.  I’m proud to say that Stu and Sara Jane are still my constituents and thriving today.  As we wish our fellow Americans well towards the long rebuilding in Florida and Houston, we also reflect on our four years of recovery. For many of us it will never be the same, but together we showed that we are #ColoradoStrong

As parents, we save for years for our kids' college education. But did you know that in Colorado and 32 other states, the cost of childcare actually exceeds the cost of college tuition? Every day, families across our state are forced to make tough decisions about childcare for their kids.   Research shows that the earliest years of a child’s life are some of the most critical. It’s incredibly important that children have the opportunity to enroll in high-quality preschool so that when they start in kindergarten, they’re ready to learn at the same level as their peers.   Despite this, less than half of three- and four-year olds in Colorado are in preschool. This is a staggering number, and it’s unacceptable. No child should be denied a good start just because of their family’s economic circumstances, and no parent should have to be faced with the burden of not being able to afford the very best for their kids.   Today, I introduced the Child Care for Working Families Act, which will finally give working families the access to child care and high-quality preschool that they deserve.   The bill would provide universal access to high-quality preschool for three and four-year olds, and it would ensure that no family making less than 150 percent of state median income pays more than seven percent of their income for child care.   Our country ranks third-to-last among developed nations for enrollment in early childhood education. We can and must do better. This bill will be an important step towards that.

Like all college degrees, a short-term certificate or an associate degree can be the ticket to a better paying job.   I'm pleased that my bill obtained praise from the University of Colorado, Colorado State University, Front Range Community College, and the Colo. Dept. of Higher Education.    This transfer bill makes it easier for students, who transferred from a community college to a four-year-institution, to apply their additional credits back toward an associate degree and facilitates credit transfer.  http://www.denverpost.com/2017/09/15/community-college-reverse-transfer-efficiency-act-credits-degrees-jared-polis/

I stopped by NSIDC today, and heard about how they are studying the changing snow, ice, glaciers, frozen ground, and how it all affects the climate.   Boulder and surrounding communities are the proud home of many science labs, like NSIDC.  As the climate changes, giving way to natural disasters, it is critical we invest in research and science.     That is why in March - along with Rep. Diana Degette, Rep. Perlmutter, and Rep. Coffman - I co-authored a bipartisan letter to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget supporting robust funding for all science and research labs in Colorado.  NSIDC works to benefit Colorado and the nation with data to help us make informed decisions about transportation, agriculture, and national security, and I am proud that it – and many other science labs – are in my district.

The bill would deny care to women in the most desperate of circumstances and is a blatant attempt to chip away at a woman’s right to choose. Today, October 5, is the arbitrary renewal deadline for the 154,000 eligible Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients.  Between 2,500 – 4,000 Coloradans are eligible for renewal to extend their DACA status for two years.  Because the Trump Administration announced it was ending the program, if Congress doesn’t act, this is the last possible renewal opportunity.    In the chaos following President Trump’s callous decision, the federal government didn’t even notify the Dreamers who needed to renew their status, and approximately 50,000 of them have yet to do so. These are 50,000 Dreamers that will begin to lose their protection from deportation as early as tomorrow.   That is why I am urging the president to extend the renewal deadline, and give these eligible DACA recipients a chance to complete their paperwork.  I have had the honor of meeting and getting to know several inspiring Dreamers, and they deserve a fair shot.    Ten months ago, when Oscar Juarez-Luna attended President Trump’s first State of the Union with me, I gave him my commitment to do everything possible to protect him and his fellow Dreamers.  He, like so many other Dreamers, exudes everything it means to be American.  He grew up here, and he wants to serve his country in our military, if only we will let him. Without DACA protection, Oscar and the hundreds of thousands of other Dreamers in the U.S., will no longer have the ability to use their talents here and pursue their dreams.   Ten months later, I’m doubling down on the commitment I made to him, and calling all members of Congress to do their job. Oscar, and 700,000 other young, aspiring Americans, can no longer wait for a permanent solution.

For far too long, only investors and CEOs have cashed in on profits, leaving hard working Americans further and further behind.  Co-ops and employee-owned businesses are one way we can ensure more people have a fair shot at the American Dream while increasing overall productivity.  Today, during National Co-op Month, I introduced a resolution commending the cooperative business model. Co-ops provide an opportunity to address inequality by putting the benefit of workers and member-owners before investors.   In my district alone, there are 86 cooperatives in a variety of industries including solar power technology, financial services, preschools, groceries, housing, and bicycle sales and repair. Those businesses give their workers an opportunity to participate in the management of a business, and that translates to higher wages.  As a member of the Congressional Cooperative Business Caucus, I will continue fighting to strengthen employee-ownership, advocate for a fairer tax code for employee stock ownership plans, and creating more worker cooperatives.

The Trump Administration just announced the repeal of the commonsense Clean Power Plan at the bidding of their special interest friends. Trump's "Dirty Power Plan" is a misguided step that will expose us to more carbon pollution and other dangerous pollutants emitted by power plants. The Clean Power Plan was a crucial health regulation- under President Obama, the EPA estimated it would have prevented up to 3,600 premature deaths and 90,000 childhood asthma attacks every year. It is also a sensible policy that would have helped reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slowed down the effects of climate change, saving billions of dollars from rising sea levels, droughts and more intense storms.   Moving our country towards clean energy, like solar and wind power, curbs greenhouse gas emissions and is a critical step in reducing our carbon footprint. Rolling back the Clean Power Plan and its essential regulations threatens our health, our safety, and our planet.   The EPA has a legal obligation to protect the environment- settled law has determined that the EPA must issue safeguards against climate pollution under the Clean Air Act, as the Supreme Court has already concluded three times. They also have a moral responsibility to limit dangerous air and water pollution, and this repeal is an egregious failure.

Last week, tragedy struck our country, as dozens of lives were senselessly taken in a mass shooting in Las Vegas. Reports indicate that the perpetrator used a device to convert a legal gun into what effectively became an illegal automatic weapon with the capacity to shoot 400-800 rounds/minute, leading to a heavy death and injury toll. While the legal ownership of fully automatic weapons such as machine guns is heavily restricted, inexpensive devices such as bump stocks can still be easily purchased to convert legal weapons into illegal ones. Hopefully that's about to change.   Today I co-authored a bipartisan bill with Rep. Curbelo (R-Fla.) and Rep Moulton (D-Mass.) that would ban the manufacture, sale, and use of bump stocks and other devices that illegally convert weapons. We have defined these devices clearly and specifically, and as a supporter of our Constitutional Second Amendment rights, I am confident that this bill will not impact legal gun owners who choose to own guns for defense, sport, or hunting. With this bipartisan approach, I hope we can begin to reduce the tragic bloodshed of mass shooting events in our country.

I am proud to introduce Medicare-X in the House of Representatives, alongside Representative Brian Higgins. Medicare-X makes a Medicare public option available by allowing individuals and small businesses to choose among existing private insurance plans and a public one. This is a strong version of the "public option" I've long supported and I'm pleased that the Senate version was introduced by Senator Michael Bennet and Senator Tim Kaine.   Medicare-X would first become available only in counties with one or zero health plans selling on the Obamacare marketplace, then expand to all areas. This is especially important for rural counties where options for healthcare are limited. Last week, when I hosted a town hall in Idaho Springs, community members expressed serious concern about their lack of options for coverage, and I’ve heard that sentiment echoed time and time again by folks in Eagle, Summit, Grand, and other rural areas of our district.    Just a few days ago, President Trump intentionally created instability and chaos in the market by stopping CSR payments. That’s why it’s more critical than ever to find a fix for the Affordable Care Act, and the reason I’m working so hard to put forth legislation to give people more choices, and bring down costs. This bicameral bill is a step in the right direction towards universal healthcare.

Did you know that an estimated 30 million dogs and cats are slaughtered each year around the world for the dog and cat meat trade? Many of these dogs and cats are stolen pets, still wearing their collars when they are painfully killed. Even more die during transportation to the slaughterhouses, deprived of food and water.  I am proud to coauthor a resolution (H.Res.401) which calls for an end to the dog and cat meat industry and urges countries that have a dog and cat meat trade – including South Korea, Vietnam, Thailand, China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Cambodia, Laos, India and others – to adopt and enforce anti-cruelty laws while affirming the United States’ commitment to advance the progress of animal protection around the world. It also urges executive branch officials to raise the issue of the dog and cat meat trade during bilateral discussions with officials from those countries. Together we can end the inhuman butchering of dogs and cats.

As we debate how we can improve the health care system in the U.S., what is often missing from the discussion is integrative and complementary forms of treatment, like acupuncture, dietary changes, meditation, and so many others. These treatments can transform lives and reduce costs.    Today, I launched the bipartisan Integrative Health and Wellness Congressional Caucus in the House of Representatives, with my Co-Chair, Mike Coffman, R-Colo. Time and again, I have worked across the aisle on health care because our health and well-being should transcend partisan politics.    This bipartisan Caucus will serve as a space for all legislators to learn about and discuss legislative opportunities to advance integrative health options. For people seeking refuge from war and natural disasters, Temporary Protected Status (TPS) can mean the difference between life or death. It allows them to temporarily, safely, and legally reside in the U.S. But like so many other protections for foreigners, the Trump Administration is threatening to end the TPS program for people from Honduras, Nicaragua, Haiti, El Salvador and Syria.  In Colorado alone, there are 1,400 TPS holders working, raising families, and contributing to the economy and their communities.   I wrote a letter to the Department of Homeland Security with several other colleagues urging the renewal of Temporary Protected Status for these countries, and asking the government to protect the over 300,000 legal TPS holders around the country who rely on the U.S. as their only safe haven.

What can be eaten, worn, and used for construction? Hemp!   It can also be used to make paper, lotion, cosmetics, rope, plastic, hair products… the list goes on and on.   And, thanks to a 2014 U.S. Department of Agriculture pilot program, industrial hemp can be grown legally.  But, red-tape currently prohibits farmers from using their water to grow it.    That’s why I introduced the Industrial Hemp Water Rights Act to make sure farmers can use their already-established water rights to grow hemp.    This bill give farmers the freedom to grow industrial hemp, start a new business, and help our agriculture  industry thrive.

Blaring, constant train horns hinder commerce, disrupt sleep, and disturb every day peace.    Through Quiet Zones, communities can lessen the disruptive noise. But, I have heard time and again from communities in Colorado that the process for establishing a Quiet Zone is overly burdensome and costly. The Fort Collins application for a Quiet Zone was even turned down in 2015.   That same year, I formally asked the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to analyze the safety of Quiet Zones and the process for establishing a Quiet Zone. Yesterday, the GAO finally published its findings. In sum, as I always suspected, our communities are right: Quiet Zones are just as safe as when train horns blare, and the process of obtaining a Quiet Zone is unnecessarily costly and inefficient.    We must remove unreasonable barriers to Quiet Zones, allowing communities a safe alternative to constant train horn noise especially in densely populated and commercial areas. I will continue to negotiate with the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) on re-working the train horn rule to help bring peace and quiet to northern Colorado!

As your Congressman, it is always a joy when my office is able to serve you or your family directly, helping you navigate through federal agencies and cut red tape.   Over the years, we have been able to help many people throughout the district.  Take Lloyd and Cecile for example:   In 2010, Lloyd found himself in the ICU for seven days with organ failure. He and his wife Cecile filed for full veteran benefits, but the Veteran’s Administration denied his claim because he was stationed in Thailand, not Vietnam. Then, the VA lost his entire record, and from 2010 until 2017, his claims were denied again and again. The stress of the entire ordeal caused Lloyd to fall even more ill. Five years ago, Colorado voters chose to amend the State Constitution to legalize the cultivation, sale, and personal use of marijuana for people 21 years of age or older. Today, Colorado is home to a growing marijuana economy with 23,000 jobs in the industry and an excess of $200 million in tax revenue which helps to fund our schools. In addition it has helped drive criminal cartels out of our state and reduced the rate of underage Coloradans using marijuana.   Colorado has proven that marijuana legalization can help fund education; provide an alternative for opioid use; create jobs; and boost the overall economy.    Colorado ought to be an example for the nation, and it is past time we lift the federal prohibition on marijuana. That’s why I’m proud to sponsor the Regulate Marijuana Like Alcohol Act, which allows each state to decide for itself whether to legalize, and will push again this year to amend the government funding bill to restrict the Department of Justice from enforcing federal marijuana laws in jurisdictions where it is legal.

“My time in the Southwest Conservation Corps was an unforgettable experience and a life changing salvation," said Ray Curry, Marine Corps veteran and former leader of a local Conservation Corp in the Southwestern U.S. “Living and working alongside other veteran crew members reminded me of the comradery and values I gained in the Marine Corps.”   Experiences like Ray’s are why I️ introduced the Veterans Conservation Act today. This bill - modeled after the original Civilian Conservation Corps of the 1930s and private and state-run corps like Ray’s - would create a national Veteran's Conservation Corps. My bill goes a long way toward solving two problems: veterans’ unemployment and the need for natural disaster assistance and public land improvements.    Veterans Conservation Corp will provide job opportunities for veterans that leverage skills they developed in the military in fields such as water safety, construction, GIS mapping, and as park rangers. It is truly a win-win. I am hopeful that we can all agree that we should support our veterans on Veteran's Day and every day through concrete, meaningful actions, while also protecting our precious public lands that we are so fortunate to share as Americans.

There’s been a lot of talk in the news lately about crypto-currency, bitcoin, and blockchain, so I wanted to give a quick explanation. Cryptocurrency is essentially digital cash, such as Bitcoin, that is created and stored through a distributed online network. Transactions are verified online through a network of computers, and then combined with other transactions to create a new block of data. That block of data is then stored across a universal ledger known as blockchain, which is a permanent record book for transactions that is updated instantly and can never be altered.   As the founder and Co-Chair of the Blockchain Caucus, I am working to modernize the law to allow cryptocurrencies to be more available to consumers by reducing IRS reporting requirements for small transactions. Deploying blockchain technology has important benefits across many areas of the economy and will hopefully lead to benefits for consumers, increased privacy, more efficiency, and new jobs.
